title: Tim Kaine = Obama? In Virginia, a risky bet for GOP
content:
The party is betting that Obama ’ s popularity will slide in Kaine 's state . | AP Photos Kaine = Obama ? In Va. , a risky bet
BURKE , Va. — For the better part of a year , Republicans have tried to make Tim Kaine look like Barack Obama ’ s political twin .
Yet despite undeniably close ties between the president and his handpicked Democratic party chief , the GOP strategy hasn ’ t shown much of a return so far : Kaine is still even against former Sen. George Allen in one of the closest — and closely watched — Senate races in the country .
In red states hosting Senate races like Missouri , Montana and North Dakota , linking the Democratic candidate to the president is a no-brainer . Running with Obama in these states is a clear loser — and the candidates know it .
But in the Old Dominion — where the president is clinging to a small but consistent polling advantage over Mitt Romney — the calculus is trickier .
The GOP ’ s big bet is that Obama ’ s popularity will slide in this quintessential battleground state just in time to take the former Democratic National Committee chairman down with him .
Yet even as Allen and his outside conservative allies pound away at Kaine ’ s connection to the president in press releases , on the air and on the stump , Kaine refuses to blink .
At a recent campaign stop with college-bound students at an Italian restaurant in Fairfax County , Kaine mentioned Obama three times — including 20 seconds into his speech when he praised the president for the country ’ s economic progress .
“ They don ’ t agree with President Obama on everything and neither do I , but I don ’ t believe Virginians fundamentally believe it is a bad idea to be a partner with the president of the United States . We ’ re a state of presidents and the commander in chief is really important in Virginia , so the whole notion that it is wrong to be a partner with the president of the United States is not something I think most Virginians buy , ” Kaine told ███ in an interview following his event .
“ That ’ s a huge difference between Allen and me . I will always be a partner with the president of the United States . ”
During a tour of a hardware store about 20 miles north in neighboring Loudoun County , Allen also repeatedly invoked the president — but in less flattering terms . Three times , Allen said he wants nothing more than to overturn “ Obamacare . ”
“ I would love to be the deciding vote to repeal Obamacare , ” he told the general manager of TART hardware as he perused a store aisle for a bucket of paint .
Allen ’ s argument is straightforward : Obama — and by extension , Kaine — have caused a crisis of confidence among business owners worried about complying with the health care law and other policies he considers hostile to job growth .

BURKE, Va. — For the better part of a year, Republicans have tried to make Tim Kaine look like Barack Obama’s political twin.

Yet despite undeniably close ties between the president and his handpicked Democratic party chief, the GOP strategy hasn’t shown much of a return so far: Kaine is still even against former Sen. George Allen in one of the closest — and closely watched — Senate races in the country.

In red states hosting Senate races like Missouri, Montana and North Dakota, linking the Democratic candidate to the president is a no-brainer. Running with Obama in these states is a clear loser — and the candidates know it.

( Also on POLITICO: Top Senate races: Va., Mass. lead list)

But in the Old Dominion — where the president is clinging to a small but consistent polling advantage over Mitt Romney — the calculus is trickier.

The GOP’s big bet is that Obama’s popularity will slide in this quintessential battleground state just in time to take the former Democratic National Committee chairman down with him.

Yet even as Allen and his outside conservative allies pound away at Kaine’s connection to the president in press releases, on the air and on the stump, Kaine refuses to blink.

At a recent campaign stop with college-bound students at an Italian restaurant in Fairfax County, Kaine mentioned Obama three times — including 20 seconds into his speech when he praised the president for the country’s economic progress.

“They don’t agree with President Obama on everything and neither do I, but I don’t believe Virginians fundamentally believe it is a bad idea to be a partner with the president of the United States. We’re a state of presidents and the commander in chief is really important in Virginia, so the whole notion that it is wrong to be a partner with the president of the United States is not something I think most Virginians buy,” Kaine told POLITICO in an interview following his event.

“That’s a huge difference between Allen and me. I will always be a partner with the president of the United States.”

During a tour of a hardware store about 20 miles north in neighboring Loudoun County, Allen also repeatedly invoked the president — but in less flattering terms. Three times, Allen said he wants nothing more than to overturn “Obamacare.”

“I would love to be the deciding vote to repeal Obamacare,” he told the general manager of TART hardware as he perused a store aisle for a bucket of paint.

Allen’s argument is straightforward: Obama — and by extension, Kaine — have caused a crisis of confidence among business owners worried about complying with the health care law and other policies he considers hostile to job growth.
